subject: Re: [junit] Design question: was Testing Private Methods

messageBody:
Nilesh Thali wrote:


> Well, nobody really needs to use any of the other methods from the outside.
> right now, that's what we have done: made those methods public so we can test
> them.
> but someone looking to use that class may get confused with all those methods.

They might. Then again, they might just use the method that suits their needs.
I'm not sure.

I would probably attempt to refine the the ItinBuilder a bit. Let's take a
look...

(I love flight management systems! They were always so fun and challenging. Of
course, we didn't have Java back then.)

public class ItinBuilder {

public void buildItins(segment[] segs);
private sortByDptrDate();
private identifyDupeSegs();
private createUniqueItins();
private createAllItins();
}

Perhaps sortByDptrDate() could take an array of Segments(?) and return them in
sorted order. The buildItins() methods might then use that, but it's available to
other clients as well. It's probably even more testable that way, as you could
mock up a collection of Segments and assert that they were returned in sorted
order.

I'm not sure, but the code seems to want more parameters and return values. You
know the implementation better than I, and there's no right or wrong answer here.
It's design, after all, and you are the world's leading authority on where you
want your design to go.

This is just what I do when faced with a private/protected method I want to test.
I see if it really wants to be a public method to add more value from the client's
perspective. If it doesn't want to go public, I default to protected access and
my tests are in the same package (different directory).

Mike
